topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Configuring NTP

body.p: This page provides detailed information on configuring Network Time Protocol (NTP) on HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade servers and, optionally, installing an NTP server on the lifecycle manager host.
HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade requires that all servers point to the same NTP server. You can use an external NTP server or configure the lifecycle manager host as a server.

ul.li: NTP clients should use only stratum 2 and higher servers (meaning stratum 1 or stratum 0).
All the Helion servers use UTC as a time zone.

body.section:
Install an NTP server on the lifecycle manager host
You can use the lifecycle manager host system as the NTP server. This is not required and you can use any appropriate NTP server, based on your organizational needs or requirements. To configure an NTP server, follow these steps:
Log in to the lifecycle manager host.sudo su -
Install the NTP package using the following command:sudo apt-get install ntp
Add your NTP servers to the /etc/ntp.conf file. The following example use servers from the NTP Pool Project:server ntp.ubuntu.com server 127.127.1.0
Note: The NTP stratum must be numerically lower than 10 (meaning stratum 9, stratum 8, etc.) in order to use as a source. If one is not available, you might be able to fudge one.
Configure system time zone using the tzselect command.
a. Change to the /usr/bin/ directory.
b. Execute the tzselect command. The available time zones are listed.
c. Select from the listed time zones by entering a number at the promnpt.
The output should be placed in /etc/profile and executed on the command line.source /etc/profile
Use the ntpq -p command to verify that your server is broadcasting. You should see a message similar to the following:ntpq -p remote refid st t when poll reach delay offset jitter ============================================================================== *ops-ae1ops-ntp0 209.51.161.238 2 u 242 1024 377 0.509 0.043 0.206 LOCAL(0) .LOCL. 10 l 76h 64 0 0.000 0.000 0.000
You can now point clients to your NTP server.

section.title: Configure all other servers as NTP clients

ol.li: SSH to the node you want to configure.
Add your NTP server IP to the clients /etc/ntp.conf file.

Configure system time zone using the tzselect command.
a. Change to the /usr/bin/ directory.
b. Execute the tzselect command. The available time zones are listed.
c. Select from the listed time zones by entering a number at the prompt.
The output should be placed in /etc/profile and executed on the command line.source /etc/profile
Restart the NTP service.service ntp restart

Verify that you have a connection to the NTP server.ntpq -pd
1 packets reassembled into response remote refid st t when poll reach delay offset jitter ============================================================================== 2 packets reassembled into response +ntp0 209.51.161.238 2 u 82 1024 377 0.286 0.117 0.349

Verify that your server shows client connections.ntpdc -c monlist
ntpdc -c monlist remote address port local address count m ver rstr avgint lstint =============================================================================== ntp0001.use 123 10.22.170.17 2365 4 4 1d0 1000 384

section.title: Fudging a stratum lower than 10
section.p: NTP uses a hierarchical, semi-layered system of time sources. Each level of this hierarchy is termed a stratum and is assigned a number starting with zero at the top. The number represents the distance from the reference clock and is used to prevent cyclical dependencies in the hierarchy.
The numerically lower the stratum value, the higher priority that clock has.

HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade uses stratum 10. Using a numerically high stratum ensures that this is only used if all external clocks fail. This will mitigate skew until external clocks return to service.
If your NTP stratum is numerically less than 10, set up your host as the time source by fudging a stratum 10.

ol.li: Configure host as a time source.
Add the following to /etc/ntp.conf to force a stratum 10.server 127.127.1.0 fudge 127.127.1.0 stratum 10
Restart the NTP serviceservice ntp restart

section.p: Using fudge to configure the local clock as stratum 10 makes NTP use the local clock when no timeservers are available. The system will only use the local clock if your system cannot access the NTP server.
